messages.original: 3 in total. Launch maneuvers were carried out.
3 in total. Flying one after another.

2 Kinzhals to Shepetivka, Khmelnytskyi Oblast.
1 Kinzhal to Hostomel, Kyiv Oblast.
2 Kinzhals to Shepetivka, Khmelnytskyi Oblast. 1 Kinzhal to Hostomel, Kyiv Oblast.
2 Kinzhals are flying further to Burshtyn, Ivano-Frankivsk Oblast.

The remaining 2 Tu-95MS carried out launch maneuvers from Arkhangelsk Oblast. 
If these are real, they should enter Ukrainian airspace in the next 70-100 minutes.
The remaining 2 Tu-95MS carried out launch maneuvers from Arkhangelsk Oblast.   If these are real, they should enter Ukrainian airspace in the next 70-100 minutes.

These launches were likely simulated, meaning that the missile attack (or at least most of it) is now over. More than 30 missiles of various types were used. I will publish a full report + the consequences later on. 
If you wish to support my work, you can do so here: 
https://buymeacoffee.com/amk_mapping
. 
Thank you for following along.

Last night and this morning, another large-scale, combined Russian missile and drone attack was carried out on Ukraine.
Missiles launched:
~14 Kh-101 cruise missiles launched from 7 Tu-95MS strategic bombers at their launch lines in southern Nizhny Novgorod Oblast.
~6 Kh-101 cruise missiles launched from 3 Tu-95MS strategic bombers at their launch lines in Kalachyovksy District, Volgograd Oblast.
~10 Kh-101 cruise missiles launched from 2 Tu-160M strategic bombers at their launch lines in southern Nizhny Novgorod Oblast.
~4 Kinzhal hypersonic aeroballistic missiles launched from 4 MiG-31K fighters at their launch lines in the vicinity of Lipetsk City, Lipetsk Oblast.
-----------------------
Ukrainian air defence work:
As of the time of writing, Ukrainian air defence is confirmed to have intercepted at least 9 Kh-101 cruise missiles.
-----------------------
The main targets for this strike were Ukrainian energy infrastructure. The following was targeted:
"Zhytomyr" 330 kV electrical substation, Zhytomyr Oblast (50.29100, 28.69980) by ~5 Kh-101s.
"Shepetivka" 330 kV electrical substation, Khmelnytskyi Oblast (50.14639, 27.0579) by ~9 Kh-101s and ~4 Kinzhals.
Unknown target in southern Khmelnytskyi Oblast by ~5 Kh-101s
Unknown target near the Ivano-Frankivsk - Ternopil border by ~5 Kh-101s
-----------------------
Keep in mind, the numbers of missiles launched may be slightly higher than what I've listed, as the number of missiles detected is often lower than actual launches.

Smoke was seen rising over Zhytomyr city following a series of Russian Kh-101 cruise missile strikes this morning. 
The strikes targeted the city's 330 kV electrical substation, resulting in widespread power outages.

This morning, a Russian Geran-2 drone struck the roof of an apartment building in Kyiv.
Judging by the speed of the drone, the altitude change, and how it was tilting towards the end of its flight, it was likely under the influence of Ukrainian electronic warfare.
At least four civilians were injured.

This morning, a Russian Geran-2 drone struck the roof of an apartment building in Kyiv.
Judging by the speed of the drone, the altitude change, and how it was tilting towards the end of its flight, it was likely under the influence of Ukrainian electronic warfare.
At least four civilians were injured.

Overnight, dozens of Russian Geran-2 drones attacked the city of Rivne. 
The main target was the city's 330 kV electrical substation, where a large fire subsequently broke out. Widespread power outages are reported.

Overnight, dozens of Russian Geran-2 drones attacked the city of Rivne. 
The main target was the city's 330 kV electrical substation, where a large fire subsequently broke out. Widespread power outages are reported.

In the Hulyaipole direction, Russian forces continued their offensive and have made significant progress over the last few days.
Following a brief partial-stabilisation of the situation, Russian forces intensified their assault operations once again and collapsed the northern section of Ukraine's defence. They repelled the most recent Ukrainian counterattacks north of the Haichur River which were aimed at expanding their bridgehead and began pushing back from the area of the agricultural buildings, eventually eliminating Ukraine's bridgehead altogether. 
From there, building on their momentum, Russian forces crossed the Haichur River into the western part of Hulyaipole, establishing a foothold on Travnya 1st street in the area of the school and the intersection with Michurina Street. The bridgehead was subsequently connected with the older bridgehead to the northwest, forming a solid front against Ukrainian defences in the western part of the city. 
These attacks across the Haichur River were done in coordination with assault operations in the city centre. Russian forces advanced from their bridgehead in the area of the hospital complex and captured the local high school, the police station, and the district museum. Once these main strongpoints were taken, they pushed further northwest to Luhova Street and linked up with the larger bridgehead in the western part of the city. They also further expanded their zone of control in the city centre, capturing additional 3-story apartment buildings and the city's administrative building. Attacks are now underway on the western part of the city centre in the direction of the northeastern edge of the Ukrainian stronghold in the high-rise blocks. 
To the south, Russian forces managed to eliminate the Ukrainian pocket in the eastern part of Hulyaipole. It's unclear how many soldiers managed to escape the operational encirclement. From there, they captured rest of the southern low-rise residential streets, while other forces managed to consolidate in at least 9 high-rise buildings of the main stronghold. Additionally, the earlier Ukrainian counterattacks west of the high-rise blocks were repelled, however Russian progress has significantly slowed here. 
+ ~4.12 km¬≤ in favour of Russia.
Military Situation In Ukraine On December 23, 2025 (Maps Update)
Military Situation In Ukraine On December 23, 2025 (Maps Update)

Russian Army Captures Andreyevka, Crushes Remaining Ukrainian Defenses In Huliaipole (Videos)
On December 23, the Russian military captured another settlement in Dnepropetrovsk from Kiev forces, and expanded its control further in the city of Huliaipole in Zaporozhye after breaking through another Ukrainian line of defenses.
The capture of Andreyevka, located on the right bank of the Haichur River in Dnepropetrovsk, was officially announced by the Russian Ministry of Defense, which noted that the 36th Guards Motorised Rifle Brigade of the 29th Army, a part of the Vostok [East] Group of Forces], led the attack on the settlement.
Further south along the Haichur in Zaporozhye, the Sever Group of Forces continues to expand its control inside Huliaipole.
Russian troops made additional gains in both the northern and southern parts of the city. They also broke through another Ukrainian defense line in the center of the city. 
Read more 
HERE

The capture of Andreyevka, located on the right bank of the Haichur River in Dnepropetrovsk, was officially announced by the Russian Ministry of Defense, which noted that the 36th Guards Motorised Rifle Brigade of the 29th Army, a part of the Vostok [East] Group of Forces], led the attack on the settlement.

Russian Armed Forces Employ New Tactic: Simultaneous Strikes on Ukraine from Four Strategic Airbases
On the night of December 23, the Russian armed forces launched one of the largest combined strikes since the beginning of winter. According to Ukraine's Air Force, the attack involved the use of 635 strike UAVs, 35 cruise missiles, and 3 'Kinzhal' aeroballistic missiles. It is reported that Russia's new tactic involved the simultaneous use of four strategic aviation airbases, making it difficult to predict strikes.
The primary targets of the attack were energy infrastructure facilities, particularly in the western part of the country.  As a result, Rivne, Khmelnytskyi, and Ternopil regions were almost completely cut off from power. Emergency power outages were also implemented in Vinnytsia, Chernihiv, Zhytomyr, Dnipropetrovsk, and Kharkiv regions. In Kyiv, metro stations were overcrowded with people seeking shelter due to an air raid alert that lasted over four hours. 
üëâ

Ukraine Acknowledges Defeat In Siversk As Russian Army Expands Control Near City (Videos)
On December 23, Ukraine finally acknowledged losing Siversk in Donetsk, as the Russian military continued to advance to the west and south of the key city.
The General Staff said in a statement that Ukrainian troops were pulled out from Siversk after a push by the Russian military, which had ‚Äúnumerical advantage‚Äù and maintained ‚Äúconstant pressure from small assault groups in difficult weather conditions.‚Äù
The decision to pull out the troops was taken to ‚Äúpreserve lives and resources,‚Äù the Ukrainian military command added, in its first comment on the defeat.
The Ukrainian acknowledgment of the defeat came as the Russian military continued to expand its control around Siversk.

STRATEGIC STRIKES AND TACTICAL GAINS: RUSSIAN FORCES TIGHTEN THE NOOSE

Priority Shift: Russian Offensive in Ukraine‚Äôs Sumy Gains Momentum
The Ukrainian military is trying to stop Russian troops in the Sumy and Krasnopillia districts by sending in troops in armored vehicles and moving special forces from the Ukrainian State Border Guard Service to the area. This indicates that the Sumy sector is becoming one of the key points of tension. 
Advancing Russian units are methodically increasing their zone of control by utilizing operational space, forcing Ukrainian units to disperse their limited reserves and weakening their defense in other sectors. Meanwhile, intense fighting continues in the Siversk sector for control of the high ground west of Siversk and the Sviato-Pokrovske area. Despite Ukrainian resistance, Russian units have advanced various sections by 1 to 4 kilometers. 
Amid the Russian offensive's success in Sumy, calls in Europe for the West to recognize the failure of its strategy and begin realistic negotiations with Moscow are growing louder.
Read more 
HERE
